title: 105_hr4064
content: The Act titled "Native American Veterans' Memorial Act of 1998" is also known as the "Short Title". It includes findings in Section 2. Congress finds that Native Americans have a strong tradition of service in the US Armed Forces, with a history of disproportionate representation and numerous Medal of Honor recipients. The National Museum of the American Indian serves as a memorial to advance understanding of Native American contributions. The National Museum of the American Indian aims to promote knowledge of Native American cultures, including their art, history, language, and contributions to society. Establishing a Native American Veterans' Memorial at the museum would highlight the proud tradition of Native American service in the US Armed Forces. The National Museum of the American Indian promotes knowledge of Native American cultures, including their art, history, language, and contributions to society. Establishing a Native American Veterans' Memorial at the museum would highlight the tradition of Native American service in the US Armed Forces. For the purposes of this Act, "Native American" refers to individuals who are members of Indian tribes or Native Hawaiians. "Native Hawaiian" refers to descendants of the aboriginal people who exercised sovereignty in Hawaii before 1778. "Indian tribe" is defined in the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. "Memorial" is the Native American Veterans' Memorial, and "Museum" is the National Museum of the American Indian. The "Commission" refers to the commission established by the Act. The term "Commission" refers to the commission established by section 5, and the term "Director" refers to the Director of the Museum. SEC. 4. AUTHORIZATION FOR ESTABLISHMENT OF MEMORIAL. The Director, in consultation with the Commission, shall construct and maintain a Native American Veterans' Memorial at the Museum mall facility. The Museum may accept gifts, bequests, or devises for the Memorial's design, construction, and maintenance. Gifts and proceeds shall be deposited in the Treasury for disbursement by the Director. The Director, in consultation with the Commission, will construct and maintain a Native American Veterans' Memorial at the Museum mall facility. Federal funds cannot be used for the design and construction costs, except for providing the site. Non-Federal sources must pay the estimated construction costs before construction can begin. SEC. 5. NATIVE AMERICAN VETERANS' MEMORIAL COMMISSION. The Native American Veterans' Memorial Commission is established to conduct a design competition for a memorial consistent with the purpose of the Museum. The Commission will select a design within a year and consult with the Director on placement and construction. The Native American Veterans' Memorial Commission consists of 12 members appointed by the President Pro Tempore of the Senate, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, and the Director. The Chairperson is selected by the Director from among the members. Initial appointments must be made by a deadline. The Native American Veterans' Memorial Commission consists of 12 members appointed by various officials. Appointments must be made within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Members serve for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and a majority constitutes a quorum. Members do not receive pay but are reimbursed for travel expenses. The Native American Veterans' Memorial Commission can procure temporary services, request personnel from federal agencies, and receive administrative support services. They are also allowed to accept gifts, bequests, or devises of services or property. The Native American Veterans' Memorial Commission can accept gifts, bequests, or devises of money and property to aid their work. Federal funds cannot be used for Commission expenses, and it will terminate 30 days after the Memorial construction is completed.
